awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Computational Joinery
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of the project is to develop the theory, techniques, and mechanical designs needed for robots to rapidly build large, rigid structures from blocks that geometrically interlock, without the need for fasteners, cement, or glue. The work is motivated by the desire to quickly assemble structurally strong buildings, furniture, and devices, in such a way that the structure may later be disassembled and the parts re-used. Fabricating in parts presents many advantages: for instance, individual components may be fabricated efficiently, packed for storage and transport, repaired or replaced as needed, and design changes can be made readily in response to changing customer needs. Design of smooth surface finishes allows applications such as modular furniture and packaging of delicate parts for shipping, and embedding mechanical or electrical components will allow rapid construction of robots and other devices.

The problem to be studied is how structures may be designed to rigidly interlock, using cycles of geometric constraints imposed by blocks to reinforce, support, and immobilize other blocks. Goals for the project include: 1) the design of joint geometries that allow a connection process that is robust to assembly and fabrication errors; 2) mechanical block designs that allow incremental construction of interlocked structures; and 3) layout algorithms that tailor assembly sequences to allow construction of desired shapes. Methods and approaches include mechanical design, development of layout algorithms, and analysis of assembly processes to ensure structural stability during construction. Experimental work includes robot assembly to validate the approach for complex structures involving hundreds of blocks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The high-level goal of the project was to study computational joinery -- the design of blocks that interlock into larger assembled structures using geometric and structural constraints. The project developed systems for assembly which offers insights on designing the geometry of components, algorithms and techniques for laying out components to form a structure, and methods for joining components together.

A major theme of inquiry was flexibility analysis. In computational joinery flexibility may enable design decisions about robot systems or about structures that robots build. Benefits of flexibility could be to allow compliance with external forces, while disadvantages exist in reducing the sturdiness and predictability of the system. The project studied fundamental and practical questions, such as: What arrangements of bodies provide the desired level of flexibility? What joint tolerances enable assembly, while providing either enough flexibility to comply to an external structure, or enough rigidity to resist external loads?

A major outcome related to rigid block assembly was "Falling into Place: Drop Assembly of Interlocking Puzzles" by Sniffen et al. [2021]. The project explored a system for assembling structures by dropping block components into place, where interlock is achieved using only gravity. Drop assembly is a promising strategy for assembly by swimming or flying robots, as it may allow structures to be built without requiring close contact with the existing structure.

In earlier work, "PuzzleFlex: Kinematic Motion of Chains with Loose Joints" by Lensgraf et al. [2019] computed motions of a planar assembly of rigid bodies connected by loose joints. The outcome is a kinematic model for collections of rigid bodies that are flexible in the aggregate. We developed an efficient method to estimate potential motions of the system that maximize deviation from the initial configuration. The paper presents various methods to verify the estimate including physical experimentation with 3D printed prototypes.

Related to the tasks of rapid prototyping, validation, and structural strength analysis, another major outcome was work on engineered composite materials and structures "Designing Composites with Target Effective Young’s Modulus using Reinforcement Learning" by Gongora et al. [2021]. We developed an RL-based design framework for composite designs with target elastic properties and material composition. The design space is parameterized as a 2D grid of constituent materials. The works studies challenges in efficiently exploring vast design spaces for achieving targeted mechanical performance.


Last Modified: 02/24/2023
Modified by: Emily Whiting

Images (1 of )
  • A system of eight rigid blocks (left), with the upper right block flexing to the right. (Right) 3D printed blocks.
    From publication: "PuzzleFlex: kinematic motion of chains with loose joints," Samuel Lensgraf, Karim Itani, Yinan Zhang, Zezhou Sun, Yijia Wu, Alberto Quattrini Li, Bo Zhu, Emily Whiting, Weifu Wang, Devin Balkcom
    Copyrighted
    Emily Whiting
    PuzzleFlex: kinematic motion of chains with loose joints
  • Robot arm assembling interlocking blocks.
    From publication: "Falling into Place: Drop Assembly of Interlocking Puzzles", Amy Sniffen, Zezhou Sun, Samuel Lensgraf, Emily Whiting, Alberto Quattrini Li, Devin Balkcom
    Copyrighted
    Emily Whiting
    Falling into Place: Drop Assembly of Interlocking Puzzles
  • (Left) Comparison of Young's modulus obtained experimentally (E) and predicted (E~) for composite designs with varying volume fraction (𝜙). (Right) Example 3D printed designs with volume fractions (𝜙) of 0.6 and 0.8, in ascending order based on Young's modulus (E).
    From publication: "Designing Composites with Target Effective Young�s Modulus using Reinforcement Learning", Aldair Gongora, Siddharth Mysore, Beichen Li, Wan Shou, Wojciech Matusik, Elise Morgan, Keith Brown, Emily Whiting
    Copyrighted
    Emily Whiting
    Designing Composites with Target Effective Young�s Modulus using Reinforcement Learning
